body: A good business model canvas should...
title: Q: Business model canvas

_items.text: have blank boxes as not every box is relevant to every business
be built on strong financial foundations
be created once your business is established, so you know what to include in the boxes

body:
Understanding your stakeholders is essentials to any project or business

In this module we explore:

  • what is a stakeholder
  • why collaborate with stakeholders
  • different types of stakeholders
  • mapping stakeholders

The final component of the pitch is to leave your potential investor with a clear action.

Listeners want to be able to take action in response to a pitch. Your task is to create an action that allows them to immediately say yes (or no) without needing to think about it.
title: What next?
instruction: Click on the headings to explore.

_items.title: On the spot
_items.body: Make sure that your listener can respond to your action on the spot. If the person needed to consult others or consider further, the action is too big. The ideal is an action that is small, clear, and moves the agenda forward.

_items.title: Clear expectations
_items.body:
Make sure that you set clear expectations to what you are asking. Aspect such as timeframe, resourcing and potential impact should all be central to expectation management. 

If the listener feels that the timeframe or resourcing constraints limit opportunity they may even be able to help. Being open and reasonable will help the listener become engaged in your pitch.

_items.title: Reasonable requests
_items.body: Only ask for budget or time that is reasonable, given the level of expected return. If your requests are unreasonable, you are unlikely to get a positive answer

_items.title: Examples of good actions
_items.body:
​​​​Good actions don't have to change the world. Examples of good actions include:

  • Getting a date in the diary for a follow-up meeting with more people
  • Them committing to read and respond to a case study relevant to their interests
  • Them sending you a feasibility assessment of using your solution.

body: A value proposition is...
title: Q: What is a value proposition?

_items.text: the problem you are solving for your users
a estimate of the value of a solution
how much money you will get

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The value proposition is the problem you are solving for your users. The value proposition of a business is central to its business model.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The value proposition is the problem you are solving for your users. The value proposition of a business is central to its business model.

body: You should end your pitch with...
title: Q: What next?

_items.text: an action that enables on the spot decision making.
an action for your listener to take to their manager.
an action for your listener to think about for a few days.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

At the end of your pitch it is vital to create an action that allows your listener to give an answer immediately. If the person needed to consult others or consider further, the action is too big.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

At the end of your pitch it is vital to create an action that allows your listener to give an answer immediately. If the person needed to consult others or consider further, the action is too big.

body: Here are some questions to test what you've learnt.
displayTitle: Are you ready to pitch an open data business?
title: Are you ready to pitch an open data business?

body:
Opening data can be a valuable activity for any organisation to make more effective use of their resources. However, most businesses are configured to protect their data resources, even where the benefits of greater sharing outweigh the costs.

Clear, effective communication of the benefits is essential to capture imaginations and gain trust and understanding. In this module we have learned how to deliver a tailored pitch for open data.
title: Summary

_items.title: What is a value proposition?
_items.body:
The value proposition of a business is the problem(s) that it is solving for its users.

If your business does not solve a problem for your users, they have no reason to interact with your service or product.

The value proposition of a business is central to its business model. Without a strong value proposition, a business does not have justification to operate.

_items.title: Why is the value proposition important?
_items.body:
The value proposition of a business is central to its business model. Without a strong value proposition, a business does not have justification to operate.

The value proposition is also the logic on which the rest of the business is based.

If a business solves a problem for its users and helps them save money or time, there is a reason to charge for this service.

If a business solves a problem that the users don't value in monetary terms, that business may need to seek alternative sources of revenue.

Without a strong value proposition, a business is unlikely to succeed.

body: Here are some questions to test what you've learnt.
displayTitle: Are you ready to build an open data business model?
title: Are you ready to build an open data business model?

displayTitle: Are you ready to overcome the barriers to open?
title: Are you ready to overcome the barriers to open?

body:
Many advocates of open data use generic arguments when discussing its advantages, but a strong pitch needs to be closely tailored to the priorities and concerns of the audience of the pitch and the decision maker.

In most cases, this can be determined from their professional context. Below we examine four common roles of decision makers, coupled with the most relevant benefits of open data.
title: What open data can do

_items.title: Leadership
_items.body: Leaders in an organisation are most likely to be convinced by the arguments that open data can help drive innovation and growth within the organisation, and improve services for users.

_items.title: Operations
_items.body:
For those in operations roles, reducing costs and being more efficient are priorities. Open data plays a crucial role in resource-saving by enabling a faster exchange of information.

The ability to access, use and share data across multiple platforms and between numerous organisations minimises the time and cost normally associated with acquiring valuable data.

_items.title: Product and marketing
_items.body: Those in product or marketing roles will respond best to the potential of open data to improve products and services.  More consumers are coming to expect a custom experience, which can be satisfied through greater provision of open data to complement existing products.

_items.title: Communications
_items.body:
For those in communications roles, open data can seem irrelevant to their work. The key message that resonates with communications professionals is that opening data can help to improve the reputation of an organisation. Open data can help to maximise opportunities for media exposure in support of promoting organisational priorities, and complement existing media channels.

As open data is easy to verify, it also increases trust that any stories are not 'spun'.

body: A value proposition is important because...
title: Q: Building a value proposition

_items.text: without a strong value proposition, a business is unlikely to succeed.
It outlines how parts of the business work together.
the value of your business

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The value proposition of a business is central to its business model. Without a strong value proposition, a business is unlikely to succeed.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The value proposition of a business is central to its business model. Without a strong value proposition, a business is unlikely to succeed.

body: The five components of a perfect data pitch include...
displayTitle: What are the five components of the perfect data pitch?
title: Q: What are the five components of the perfect data pitch?

_items.text: the problem you are solving
a tailored description of the benefit
a relevant example
justification for why it beats other options
a realistic decision that can be taken on the spot
a complicated description designed to impress
a big decision in order to succeed

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The perfect pitch should be structured around the following five components:

  1. What it is – the problem you are solving for your users
  2. What is can do – a tailored description of the benefit
  3. Where it's helped – a relevant, quantified proof point
  4. Why it's best – justification for why it beats other options
  5. What next – a realistic decision that can be taken on the spot

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The perfect pitch should be structured around the following five components:

  1. What it is – the problem you are solving for your users
  2. What is can do – a tailored description of the benefit
  3. Where it's helped – a relevant, quantified proof point
  4. Why it's best – justification for why it beats other options
  5. What next – a realistic decision that can be taken on the spot

body:
Creating an effective pitch for open data requires five elements. When brought together, these create a clear, compelling case for action that can be used when seeking management approval, budgetary and resource support and downstream use and re-use. The pitch should be delivered in 90 seconds or less.

The five components of the perfect pitch are:

  1. What it is – the problem you are solving for your users
  2. What it can do – a tailored description of the benefit
  3. Where it's helped – a relevant, quantified proof point
  4. Why it's best – justification for why it beats other options
  5. What next – a realistic decision that can be taken on the spot

Below we explore each of these components in more detail.
displayTitle: The five components of the perfect pitch
title: The five components of the perfect pitch

_items.title: Using pricing
_items.body:
One way is to price your products or services, whilst maintaining the same costs. Alternatively, you could reduce the cost of production.

You might think that increasing your prices will automatically increase your profits, but there are other factors that you need to consider.

You need to check your prices against the competition. Open data on pricing information and consumer trends will help you compare.

It's also possible that changing your pricing may influence your sales. Higher prices may lead to fewer sales.

_items.title: Increasing efficiency
_items.body:
Many organisations see the commercial value of data, and adjust their spend accordingly. There is also a time factor involved in sourcing datasets and arranging contracts or data sharing agreements.

Using open data is a great way to save time and money involved in sourcing and acquiring valuable datasets individually.

body: Here are some questions to test what you've learnt.
displayTitle: Are you ready to grow an open data business?
title: Are you ready to grow an open data business?

body:
Open data isn't just useful for startups looking to innovate with data, it is also a crucial source to grow and develop your business. A business grows by increasing sales or by increasing its profitability and open data can support both of these activities.

​​​​​​In this module we will explore:

  • Increasing sales with open data
  • Improving offer with open data
  • Increasing profitability with open data
displayTitle: Growing a business with open data
title: Growing a business with open data

body: Changing your pricing is one way to increase profitability. How can open data support your pricing model?
title: Q: Increasing your profitability

_items.text: Open data on pricing and consumer trends will help you adjust your prices.
Open data will encourage investors to invest in your business and increase profitability.
Transparency about pricing will encourage more consumers.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Open data on pricing and consumer trends will help you adjust your prices. You will need to check your prices against the competition.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data on pricing and consumer trends will help you adjust your prices. You will need to check your prices against the competition.

body: Open data can help you increase sales by...
displayTitle: Increasing your sales with open data
title: Q: Increasing your sales with open data

_items.text: helping you to identify potential customers
doing all the work so you don't have to
making your sales team redundant

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Open data can help you to identify potential customers with sources such as demographics, disposal income, economic sectors and use of (mobile) internet by households helping you to build up a bigger picture.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data can help you to identify potential customers with sources such as demographics, disposal income, economic sectors and use of (mobile) internet by households helping you to build up a bigger picture.

displayTitle: Increasing your sales with open data
title: Increasing your sales with open data

_items.title: Know your competition
_items.body:
Whether you're a startup or an established business, it pays to know who your competition is.

If your target audience are buying similar products or services from a competitor, your sales will be lower.

Company data is published openly by many governments worldwide. You can compare which data is open in which company with the Open Company Data Index.

OpenCorporates is an open data base of companies worldwide.

_items.title: Broadening your customer base
_items.body:
A relatively simple tactic to increase your sales is to increase the location of your sales. Since you have already a good profile of the existing customer base, you only need to find similar ‘customers’ in a broader area. If your product or service is heavily based on open data, you need to be certain of the availability of data in the new region or country.

Investigate if your product or service can also be of use for other types of customers who have the same needs as your existing customers, for example of a different age, income level or industry segment.

Use open data to help you identify those customers. There are a vast range of datasets that will be able to help you, such as data on demographics, disposal income, economic sectors and use of (mobile) internet by households and companies and many more.

_items.title: Getting your timing right
_items.body:
Open data can help you target new B2B audiences at the right time by providing insights about other companies.

Finish startup Vainu have built their business around using data and open data to maximise sales for other organisations.

For example, open data about company mergers and acquisitions, new hires, structure changes, new products and anniversaries can provide event organisers with a better idea of when to target these customers.

body:
Open data can help you diversify your offering by enriching your existing data.

If you are an aggregator who already collects and aggregates data to sell to the customers, open data can enrich your data. Transport API are the UK's single, comprehensive source of UK transport information. They aggregate data from this sources which they then clean and combine into one API saving other companies time and money.

If your value comes from analysing data and identifying insights, you can integrate open data to diversify that insight. For example, Zoopla uses transport data from TfL as well as property data from Land Registry to help its users search for suitable properties.

If you are a developer, you can include additional data in your application. Should I go? combines multiple open data sources on locations and weather conditions to enhance their application for tourists.
displayTitle: Improving your offer with open data
title: Improving your offer with open data

body: What is one way that open data can help you to improve your offer?
displayTitle: Improving your offer with open data
title: Q: Improving your offer with open data

_items.text: Open data is another source from which insight can be derived.
Open data makes your products more desirable.
Open data increases the transparency of your business operations.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Many businesses make their money from analysing data and selling insights. Open data is another source that can be analysed and used to find new, diverse insights.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Many businesses make their money from analysing data and selling insights. Open data is another source that can be analysed and used to find new, diverse insights.

body:
Open data isn't just useful for startups looking to innovate with data, it is also a crucial source to grow and develop your business. A business grows by increasing sales or by increasing its profitability and open data can support both of these activities.

From making your business more efficient by removing many of the manual tasks involved, to helping you identify new opportunities to grow and comparing your business to competitors, more and more businesses are using open data.
displayTitle: Growing a business with open data
title: Growing a business with open data

body:
Opening data can be a valuable activity for any organisation. Whether to drive innovation in the business, develop a clearer picture of operations or improve products and services, a growing number of private and public sector organisations now benefit from publishing and using open data.

But opening data might require a change in the culture of an organisation. Most organisations are configured to protect their data resources, even when the benefits of openness outweigh the costs. The key to overcoming this resistance is clear, effective communication of the benefits that open data can and is bringing.

This module will prepare you to deliver a tailored pitch for open data that highlights value and addresses risks.

In this module we'll explore how to:

  • structure the perfect pitch
  • identify different audiences for your pitch
  • tailor your pitch to different audiences
title: Pitching for open data

body:
You should start your elevator pitch by outlining the problem you are solving for your users. This is known as the value proposition.

The value proposition of a business is central to its business model. This is equally relevant in the private and public sectors. Without a strong value proposition, the organisation - whether a large corporation, a startup, a local authority or a charity -  does not have justification to keep delivering its services.

Top tip: think of your value proposition as the abstract or executive summary of your solution. Keep it short, keep it snappy and use a list of three.

For example: open data can enhance your business' reputation, improve your customers' experience and diversify your product portfolio.
title: What problem are you solving?

body:
This is the part of your pitch where you can explain your value proposition in more detail. Don't worry about repeating yourself. Repetition is key.

The first time you said your value proposition, you wanted to catch your audience's attention. Now you have their attention, and you've explained the benefits for them, you can explain your solution in more detail.

This is also your chance to justify why your solution is better than alternative solutions. You can give competitive examples if relevant, or examples of where data has been shared with positive consequences to emphasise your point. 

Use a list of three for maximum impact, and remember: repetition is key.
title: Why it's best

body: The next step in the pitch is to introduce real-life examples of where open data has already helped. In this section, we explore some existing case studies, grouped by the benefits identified in unlocking value from open data.
displayTitle: What open data has already done
title: What open data has already done
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Driving innovation and growth
_items.body:
Open data drives innovation and growth in businesses by revealing opportunities to enrich products or services and make better business decisions.

Finnish company Vainu maximise lead generation and sales by using open data, whereas in Spain BBVA offer the competitive edge using data analytic services.

Open data stimulates innovation and growth by removing barriers to access, use and shareability of data.

_items.title: Improving service delivery
_items.body:
Open data can help organisations improve services for users. Organisations enable their users to make decisions based on easily comparable data and information.

Available in over 400 cities across the world, Austrian-based Bike Citizens are combining open data from cycle schemes and maps to improve the urban cyclist’s experience.

Open data is being used in the Netherlands to reduce the barriers facing disabled people  by allowing them to book transport and navigate their area more easily.

Czech company DATLOWE have created a comprehensive Drug Encyclopaedia as a guide for patients and medical professionals to easily compare ingredients found in medication.

_items.title: Reducing costs
_items.body:
Open data can help businesses reduce their costs and be more efficient in their operations.

Swedish music-streaming giant Spotify and the UK’s BBC both use open data service MusicBrainz to complement their music services and enhance their users’ experience without having to invest in maintaining the catalogue themselves.

In Slovenia, winegrowers are using open data to help them make smarter growing decisions, whereas in Hungary, a revolution to stop food waste is underway, built on open data and collaboration.

_items.title: Improving reputation
_items.body:
Open data can help improve the reputation of an organisation. As the data is openly available, it helps to increase perceived neutrality and trust among the public that the results are not ‘spun’.

In the UK, open data helps inform consumers about the origins and journeys of their purchases, whereas in Bulgaria, citizens can analyse open election data.

_items.title: Social impact
_items.body: Open data is helping us tackle one of the biggest environmental problems: air quality. Using open weather, air quality and traffic data, ‘CityTrees’ in Germany can reduce air pollution within 50 metres by 30%. In Greece, Envi4All makes it easier for locals to find out about air pollution levels in their area.

body: Which argument for open data is the most appropriate in a pitch for the Head of Operations?
title: Q: What can open data do?

_items.text: Open data can improve the reputation of an organisation
Open data can reduce costs
Open data can drive innovation

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Reducing costs and being efficient are priorities for those in operations roles. The ability to access, use and share data across multiple platforms and between numerous organisations minimises the time and cost normally associated with acquiring valuable data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Reducing costs and being efficient are priorities for those in operations roles. The ability to access, use and share data across multiple platforms and between numerous organisations minimises the time and cost normally associated with acquiring valuable data.

body:
Open data is a relatively new concept. Any change will bring barriers - challenges for some current ways of working, or barriers for those who want to use open data but can't.

In this module we will explore how to overcome the barriers open data creates for established businesses.

In this module:

  • Why are there barriers?
  • Overcoming technical barriers
  • Overcoming non-technical barriers
title: Overcoming barriers  for established businesses

body:
Open data is relatively new, and new tools and concepts take a while to be widely adopted.

Additionally, established businesses were configured before open and open data, and so they weren’t designed to incorporate open data. Some IT systems, internal data policies or businesses models create significant barriers for businesses looking to incorporate open data into their daily work. Working in the open may also require a significant culture shift for some organisations who are configured around protecting their resources and IP.

Barriers that open data may create for established businesses can be split into two categories: technical barriers, and non-technical barriers. We explore both categories in more detail below.
title: Why are there barriers?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body:
Businesses working in the open – whether built on open source or open data – need to carefully consider their value proposition. This is because value propositions built on open are fundamentally different from those built on traditional closed approaches. They do not rely on exclusive access to to data, code or information. 

These new models present  new opportunities that are not possible through more traditional models. This comes from using, publishing or both using and publishing open data.
title: The value proposition of open

_items.title: Value from using open data
_items.body:
The main difference when using open data instead of proprietary data is that everyone has the same access that you do.

The value proposition of companies using open data is entrenched in what they do with the data. For example, cleaning, formatting or enriching open data with to either create new products and insights, or enhance existing products. Crucially, the service or product provided must be of higher value to the client than them performing the same task themselves. This could be that it is cheaper than doing it in-house or that it is quicker and therefore reduces the time to market.

Emu Analytics provide geospatial data analytics using open data. They also create DataPacks of enriched open data about buildings in the UK, some of which are re-released as open data and some which are premium.

Geolytix use a wide range of open data sources to help retail sector clients make more informed  decisions on the location and number of stores and the optimisation of home delivery and click and collect operations.

_items.title: Value from publishing open data
_items.body:
More and more companies are gaining value from publishing open data.

Publishing open data can push your users to other services that you offer. For example, Austrian startup Bike Citizens publish the location of their hire bikes. This means that consumers can more easily find the bikes, and therefore use the service that is provided.

Another benefit of publishing open data is so that your users become reliant on that data. Similar to a freemium model, you can then charge for additional services.

For example, OpenCorporates publish open data on companies worldwide. They provide open access to structured data for anyone working in the public good, but they charge proprietary data users for access to structured data.

body:
More and more businesses are using open data, from large corporations to startups. When starting a business with open data, it is important to design your business model and consider how open data will underpin that model.

​​​​​​Building a valid business model is essential to having a successful open data business.

In this module we explore:

  • The business model canvass
  • Building a value proposition
  • The value proposition of open
  • Cost and revenue models of open
displayTitle: Starting a business with open data
title: Starting a business with open data

body:
Making money from open data is also important to starting a business with open data. For businesses that use open data, these revenue models tend to be similar to other companies using data, for example by providing insights or structured data.

It is also possible to make money from publishing open data. Most businesses making money from open data tend to adopt a freemium model. In a freemium model, a base product or service is provided free of charge, but money is charged for proprietary features or functions.
title: Making money from open data

body: Such features could include charging:

_items.title: By volume of data
_items.body: Free tiers may offer access to a set volume of data per day, while paid tiers provide higher rates or no-limits.

_items.title: By usage licence
_items.body: Fee tiers might offer data under a sharealike licence, while paid tiers might allow customers to keep their derived data closed.

_items.title: For support and guarantee
_items.body: Free tiers might not offer technical support or guarantee on availability, while paid tiers provide service level agreements and customer support.

_items.title: By time period covered
_items.body: Free tiers might offer access only to historic data, while paid tiers offer more recent data, or visa versa.

_items.title: By frequency of update
_items.body: Free tiers might offer delayed access to data while paid tiers get data in real-time.

_items.title: By access method
_items.body: Free tiers might offer a download of tabular data while charging for access to an API.

_items.title: By subset
_items.body: Free tiers may include only a subset of the entire dataset, while paid tiers might offer additional fields or API methods.

body:
A useful tool for getting started with your open data business is to use the business model canvas.

The business model canvas offers a logical view of a business. It is key to identifying any areas of strengths, weakness or potential opportunity.

The canvas is formed of nine key boxes: key partners, key activities, key resources, cost structure, customer segments, customer relationships, channels and revenue streams.

In the middle of the canvas is the value proposition. This is the most important aspect of the canvas and of your business as without a strong value proposition, a business does not have justification to operate.
title: The business model canvas

body: Which of the following are value propositions of publishing open data?
title: Q: The value proposition of open
instruction: Select all that apply and then click 'submit'

_items.text: Encourage your clients to use your other products and services
Clients become reliant on your data
There is no value proposition

_feedback.correct:
Well done!

Publishing open data can push your users to other services that you offer and make them users become reliant on your data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Publishing open data can push your users to other services that you offer and make them users become reliant on your data.

body: How can you make money from publishing open data?
title: Q: Making money from open data

_items.text: By charging for additional features or functions
By giving away all your data for free
By putting a non-commercial use clause in your licence

_feedback.correct:
Well done!

You can make money from publishing open data by adopting a freemium model. This is where you have a base product that is available for free, and you charge for additional features or functions.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

You can make money from publishing open data by adopting a freemium model. This is where you have a base product that is available for free, and you charge for additional features or functions.

body:
More and more businesses are using open data, from large corporations to startups. When starting a business with open data, it is important to design your business model and consider how open data will underpin that model.

Having a valid value proposition is essential to starting a business model with open data, whether as a user or as a publisher.
title: Summary

body: Some of the main barriers facing established businesses are technical in nature.
title: Overcoming technical barriers

_items.title: Quality and reliability - as a consumer
_items.body:
A barrier for consuming open data as a core part of the business is questions around the quality and reliability of that data.

How do you know your data source will be regularly updated, that your rights to use it will be guaranteed, and that the data itself is accurate?

Things to look for that tell you the open data is quality:

  • Has the data been updated regularly?
  • Does the publisher commit to keeping the data open?
  • Has the publisher included contact details?
  • Are there details of the publisher's quality control process?

There are two quality marques that will help you with assessing open data quality, Open Data Certificate and 5 Stars of Linked Open Data. You can find out more about these quality marques in What makes quality open data?

_items.title: Quality and reliability - as a publisher
_items.body:
Many businesses are reluctant to publish open data as they feel that any errors will reflect badly on the organisation.

Sometimes good quality open data depends on the needs of the person using it. Publishing that data openly can lead to better data and spreads the load in improvement.

For example UK released data on location of 300,000 bus-stops; OpenStreetMap corrected 18,000 of them, improving official data accuracy. You can read more examples in this document put together by Open Knowledge.

For quick fixes, spreadsheet programmes and OpenRefine can help you. Find out more about getting your data ready to publish in How to clean your data.

_items.title: Lack of open data skills
_items.body:
The skills and knowledge to use open data effectively may not currently exist in the organisation.

To overcome this barrier, you need to identify which skills are required or undertake a skills gap analysis. Once you know what is missing, then seek either to develop existing staff, hire new capacity or outsource delivery.

The Open Data Skills Framework is a useful tool to help you identify skills gaps, either as an individual or in a team.

_items.title: Legacy systems and processes
_items.body:
Many systems were built or procured before the need to use open data, so they were not designed to include it.

Legacy systems and processes often mean that it is very difficult to do new things. Whilst this is not a barrier that can be immediately overcome, you may be able to make small changes. Speak to your IT department, or to your procurement department. Explain to them what you want to do and why you want to do it, and they may be able to find a way around it.

body: Why are there barriers for established businesses looking to work with open data?
title: Q: Why are there barriers?

_items.text: Many businesses need to adapt in order to be compatible with open data.
Open means giving away your products and services for free.
Open data is exclusive to the public sector.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Few established businesses were designed to incorporate open data, and so IT systems, internal data policies or businesses models create significant barriers. Working in the open may also require a significant culture shift for some organisations.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Few established businesses were designed to incorporate open data, and so IT systems, internal data policies or businesses models create significant barriers. Working in the open may also require a significant culture shift for some organisations.

body:
Open data is a relatively new concept. Any change will bring barriers - challenges for some current ways of working, or barriers for those who want to use open data but can't.

Some barriers are technical in nature, such as the quality and reliability of available open data, a lack of open data skills within an organisation and legacy systems and processes. Some barriers are non-technical in nature, such as open data undermining the business model of the company, and a lack of buy-in, support and understanding of open data.

The key to overcoming the challenges is through education - upskilling the team to overcome the technical barriers and helping colleagues to understand that open data provides a opportunity for any established business.
title: Summary

body: Some of the main barriers facing established businesses are non-technical in nature. Embracing open might require a change in the revenue model or culture of an organisation.
title: Overcoming non-technical barriers

_items.title: Threat to business model
_items.body:
Open data can be a threat or a risk to an existing business model, particularly if the business model is selling data.

You could choose to ignore it, but in many fields, open is now considered inevitable. Wouldn't it make more sense to adapt now? 

What insight could you offer? Could you combine the data with other data to add value/find insight?

For example, Landmark used to sell government data about the environmental impact of the HS2 project in the UK. Once the data was made open, the company restructured to provide additional insights and analysis from that same data.

You can find out more about how open data can enhance your business in Starting a business with open data and Growing a business with open data.

_items.title: Lack of open data culture
_items.body:
Adopting open data will often require a change in the way a business operates. This kind of change is known as a culture change. Open data needs to be at the heart of the business’ culture in order to maximise its impact.

An open data culture means that open data is considered at every decision making point, at every change in strategy and every new initiative.

Active support from senior figures can help to encourage organisational buy-in.

Strong open data leadership and active engagement with key stakeholders is key to a successful open data initiative.

Find out more about open data and culture change for governments and for businesses.

_items.title: Lack of buy-in
_items.body:
You might be bought in to the idea of open data, but you will need wider support to make that a reality. Convincing your colleagues, manager or CEO to the value of open data is one of the biggest barriers.

The way to overcome this barrier is to have a strong vision that you can clearly articulate. Work out which benefits of open data are most likely to persuade the person that you are trying to convince, and include real life case studies and examples that are relevant to the point you are making.

Find out more about convincing others in Pitching for open data.

body: How can you overcome issues of quality and reliability as a consumer of open data?
title: Q: Overcoming technical barriers

_items.text: Assess the quality of the data against quality marques
Hope for the best
Don't use the data as it is too risky

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

There are two quality marques that will help you with assessing open data quality, Open Data Certificate and 5 Stars of Linked Open Data.

Things to look for that tell you the open data is quality:

  • Has the data been updated regularly?
  • Does the publisher commit to keeping the data open?
  • Has the publisher included contact details?
  • Are there details of the publisher's quality control process?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

There are two quality marques that will help you with assessing open data quality, Open Data Certificate and 5 Stars of Linked Open Data.

Things to look for that tell you the open data is quality:

  • Has the data been updated regularly?
  • Does the publisher commit to keeping the data open?
  • Has the publisher included contact details?
  • Are there details of the publisher's quality control process?

body: Open data might be a threat to your business model. How can you overcome that risk?
title: Q: Overcoming non-technical barriers

_items.text: Use open data as an opportunity to enhance your products or services
Refuse to accept that your business model might need to change
Sell your company

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Open data can help you to enhance your existing products and services or provide an opportunity to create new products and services. 

You can find out more about how open data can enhance your business in Starting a business with open data and Growing a business with open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data can help you to enhance your existing products and services or provide an opportunity to create new products and services. 

You can find out more about how open data can enhance your business in Starting a business with open data and Growing a business with open data.
